posts.com:
I happen to own this cookbook from the depression era (1930) that offers not only a good load of cheap recipes to make, but also meal plans for up to 4 weeks per season, and also special diets for people attempting to lose weight, and those hoping to gain some.

If any of you fellas would want anything from it, be it weird sandwich recipes, poultry, desserts, or even beverages and breads, name it and I'll happy to peruse in it for you.
Note that it contains some ingredients which might no longer exist today, or atleast having been overwhelmingly replaced by other stuff. I recall attempting to make a type of 'vegetarian' meal in it, which included a 'meat substitute' composed of beans and nuts.

The problem is that nearly all of it is housewife experiments.
The chicago Daily news organized a 'cooking contest' where readers could send a recipe to be published. There was an incentive to be original since they wouldn't publish 50 of the same apple pie recipe in the same book, so each housewife figured they could add a 'trick' to their recipe, to make them into 'new' recipes.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18911631
Washing rice. This is some really crappy long grain white rice I got really cheap. Rinse the rice until the water is no longer cloudy...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911646
..like this!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911656
Drain the rice as well as you can.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911661
For this amount of rice, I'm using 1 single canned chipotle pepper in adobo sauce. A bit more than a tablespoon. You have to be careful, if you use too much it will be too spicy for most people.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911672
Rice, chipotle, a little bit of salt and oil go on high heat to start getting up to temp. The best way to make rice on a stovetop in my experience, is to get everything up to hot and boiling as fast as possible, and then seal it off to steam ASAP. Might as well heat up the rice before you add liquid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911682
This was 1 cup of rice. I'm adding 0.75 cup of smoky pork/chicken stock, and 0.75 cup of water, for a ratio of 1:1.5 rice to liquid. If you can, bring the liquid to a boil before you measure it in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911690
As soon as it reaches a full boil...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18904130
Thanks for a good thread, Anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911699
...shut off the heat, and do whatever you can to close it up. Maybe don't attempt to seal it like a pressure cooker, but you want the least amount of steam escaping as possible.

Also, you want to leave the pot on the heat source. If you remove it, whatever cool surface you place it on will leech the heat from the pot and your rice may not cook thoroughly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911714
45 minutes later, rice should be finished. You can let it go longer if you have any doubts, it won't burn or anything. Fluff it with a fork and let it sit for 5-10 minutes. With this chipotle rice, normally I would add a bit of lime zest/juice and cilantro at this point, but I had none of that. It's still pretty good...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911728
...bottom of pot shown, nothing burnt or stuck. Perfectly cooked rice!

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18911747
Here is the liquid from the marinade.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911759
Hard to tell but I eye-balled about 1.5 TBSP cornstarch, 1/2 cup sugar, and 1/2 cup white vinegar. I just like to eye-ball sauces... the only really important volume is the cornstarch. If making a cornstarch-based sauce, I would always do less than you think. You can always add more later, although it's important if you add cornstarch to a hot liquid, you must create a slurry first with cornstarch and cold water, other wise it will clump badly, and you will need a blender to fix it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911777
For cornstarch to activate as a thickener, you need to bring the sauce right up to a simmer. When you first add the cornstarch, it will make the sauce appear more opaque, and you can tell the sauce is ready because it will start to turn translucent again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911784
After letting the sauce cool for a bit, I zested some orange, lemon, and lime in and squeezed a bit of their juice. The reason I didn't do this before is because heat damages these flavors, this way it will taste more fresh and vibrant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911790
Whisked together and done. This sauce came out really nice. I was shooting for something similar to sweet & sour sauce, with a slight bitterness from the citrus and I think I nailed it. Not too bitter, tangy, sweet, very citrusy.

>>18900636
>Could I still gong fu brew it with a gawain like
A cheap porcelain gaiwan is all you really need. Yixing maybe makes a slight difference but it is not work worrying about when starting out.

>If i keep the boxes I have closed and outside of light they should last a long time right?
Those teas should be fine indefinitely if they came sealed up well. You could stick the boxes in a ziplock bags for additional protection if you want. How did the tea come stored in the boxes?

>>18900733
>Is an electric kettle with a temperature setting where it can keep the water at a certain temp necessary?
For puerh boiling or just off boiling water is what is typically used. An electric kettle that you can set to lower temperatures is nice for green tea and being able to keep the water hot is convenient but you don't need one starting out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18880148
I opened up my first 2018 Taetea V93 tuo tonight. Bought it on Amazon via the official store for pretty cheap. $35.99 USD for 500g.
It pried open easily, despite feeling more compressed than the typical DaYi cake. I've been enjoying it all night. Not in any particularly scientific way, but just enjoying it casually as I would for a daily drinker like I'm hoping this to be.
The first few brews are solid. It's mild and earthy flavor with a hint of roasted nuts. Maybe a little flat to a fault, but it could also be the recent transport through a damn cold winter. I also inexplicably brewed it with a little less material than I usually do. Either way, the flavors of the tea are what you'd expect from a shou of its age, but dialed back compared to a 7572.
From the smell of the leaves, perhaps there's just a little bit of sweetness trying to come out that I haven't found yet. Been playing around 190-200 degrees F.
Not a bad tea at all! Given the price and shipping availability from Amazon, I could see it being a daily work beater. Given the nice little 100g tuos it comes as, it's also the tea I would give to friends getting into the hobby.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: What variety of tea has the highest caffeine and theanine content? I believe the highest for theanine is matcha, but I could be wrong. It's hard getting a straight answer for caffeine though. And I have found articles that contradict each other claiming that young sheng has more then young shou, and vice versa. It doesn't help that most resources are trying to sell me something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18916543
We have much better artificial sources for both, I'd personally drink whatever you want and simply supplement whichever you want more of. For both theanine and caffeine, I believe it's matcha since you ingest the whole leaf. It's difficult to measure because what you actually care about is how much your body absorbs when you drink it. The most L-theanine will be in young shoots harvested in the spring that are steamed. Sencha, gyokuro, and matcha are comparable in this case, puerh seems to have a lower l-theanine content, maybe because of the kill-green. Having said that, the differences are a fraction of the total amount of L-theanine present in the leaves, it doesn't really matter. Having said THAT, we don't actually even care, because how much L-theanine is present in the leaves doesn't really tell us anything. Again, matcha wins here (gram for gram) because you eat the whole leaf. However, I drink thirty or so grams of tea a day, and I doubt you will be consuming an equivalent amount of matcha.

tl;dr too many confounding factors just take L-theanine or caffeine if you want more of either. If not, just drink tea and stop worrying about it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18916543
Caffeine content in tea is all over the place, impossible to say one type has more caffeine then others, varietal, harvest season, and environment probably have the largest effects on caffeine content. How the tea is processed (black, green etc) doesn't change the amount of caffeine in the leaves

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
is absolutely fucking delicious, and super healthy.

a russian friend of mine introduced me to it. since then i've given up all carbs except buckwheat (and potatoes occasionally).

it's whole grain, it's gluten-free, it taste absolutely delicious (as long as you make sure to put lots of butter/tallow and good amount of salt in).

it's imo the tastiest carb, and one of the healthiest if not the healthiest carb out there.

idk why the health fad is onto quinoa but not buckwheat. quinoa taste like shriveled up rice while buckwheat taste based and wholesome.

it's hard to describe the taste to those of you who haven't tried it. but basically it's similar to rice but it taste more earth-y and wholesome

ez recipe:

1. combine 1 cup of buckwheat, 1.5-2 cups of water (depends on how fluffy you want it), 0.5-1 teaspoon of salt, and a good chunk of butter in a saucepan
2. bring pot to boil, reduce heat to simmer and simmer for 15 mins
3. after 15 mins check the pot - you shouldn't see any visible liquid in there. turn off heat and let sit for 10 minutes.
4. eat. add more butter/salt if you want

The one i make myself, just a simple vinegar based sauce.

50g Scotch bonnets, 120g generic red chillies for flavour not heat, half a small onion, 3 cloves of garlic, 240ml apple cider vinegar, 5g salt. Chop all of it and add everything to a sauce pan, simmer for 10 minutes, let cool slightly then add to a blender untill smooth.

>>18905336
My favorite hot sauces (3 fermented, 3 non-fermented):
>Marie Sharp's Habanero Pepper Sauce
Just an all-around delicious habanero sauce. Carrot base gives it a thicker texture and a nice base for the flavor.
>Palo Alto Fire Fighter's Habanero Pepper Sauce
I think of it as a gourmet version of taco bell hot/fire sauce. Japaleno & Habanero base, with strong paprika and cumin flavor.
>El Yucateco Chile Habanero
Yet another non-fermented Habanero sauce, this time with some more garlic. Yet again, a delicious spicy sauce.

Now, for the fermented sauces.
>Frank's Red Hot
Classic fermented cayenne & vinegar, with a little garlic. Grew up with Frank's & butter being the go-to wing sauce.
>Huy Fong Sriracha
Your basic bitch Sriracha, just a nice fermented chili / garlic / sugar / vinegar like so many, but a nice, distinctive set up peppers.
>Tabasco Family Reserve Pepper Sauce
Like your standard Tabasco, but with the "funk" kicked up a notch. Everything that's good about Tabasco is better in their Family Reserve sauce. The simplest ingredients list of any sauce on this list (no thickeners, preservatives, or anything) - just white wine vinegar, red chili peppers (proprietary, of course), and salt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Prep is the workhorse of the kitchen. The biggest issue is you need to bang everything out (and if you work in a from scratch kitchen you will basically never be able to 'finish' what you need to do in a day; it's all about triaging what is important) and ideally it comes out EXACTLY the same way every time. Plus this isn't like fucking up a lamb or bruschetta that you can refire and have in the window in a realistic time. Some of things you're making taking hours to days to make and in huge volumes.
Rolling into the kitchen at 5am and getting 6 hours to yourself is bliss though. Make some bomb coffee. Put on your music. No ticket machine going off or expo yelling for shit. No delivery app shit jingling. Plus you get to peace at 2-3pm and be like "k bye have fun getting spitroasted during the rush". Plus if you really enjoy using a knife you'll like prep more. I genuinely love cutting 10lbs of onions or banging out a 50lb box of carrots or peeling a metric fuck ton of potatoes.
But it's a completely different beast than working the line. Nothing on prep is comparable to running the line during an insane service. Running a 300 cover (or whatever cover number is inane for your place) night and everything going perfect is a sublime feeling. Plus the daytime servers are usually older and not nearly as flirty and fun as the night servers and flirting with servers is one of the best perks of the job. Also, depending on the restaurant, prep can be really isolating. Even more so than working closing shifts 6 days a week. For me I'm the only prep person. At most I see one other cook, the day time 'prep' who mostly just portions and helps the line, and the single server that runs brunch/lunch service. Compare that to running with 6+ people on the line, having an expo to shit talk with, a dishie to joke around with, and a gaggle of attractive early 20s servers most of whom are definitely keen on riding the cook carousel.

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1kg flour
800g (about 5) potatoes mashed
400g butter
50g salt
3 egg yolks
150ml milk
two packets dry yeast.
boil peel and mash the potatoes. yeast goes in the milk with some sugar. flour butter and potatoes combine, and the yeast and milk, yolks, let it mix a minute, add the salt. knead that shit, refrigerate for an hour, roll out 2cm thick, separate into rolls, let rise, brush with egg, bake 200c
>my faggot breadmaker can't fit 2kg of ingredients
sad

>>18909607
>so that should make it much quicker to recoup the cost of the breadmaker
i'll break down the math for you. let's be generous and assume we don't buy $1.75 store brand garbage bread but instead we buy something decent like farmhouse for $4. let's also buy our bread ingredients in bulk to bring the cost of each loaf made down to $1. we save at best $3/loaf so you're payoff time is going to come down to how much bread you actually go through. if you have a family and couple of kids so maybe you go through 2 loaves a week at which point you have a yearly savings of $312/year. that saving can buy you a very nice bread machine and you will get your money back by the end of a year. for me, the savings is only half of that because i only go through one loaf per week at best. do i really want to invest $2-300 if it's going to take me multiple years to break even? meh, guess it depends if i want to pick up a new hobby.

>>18914677
Kroger sells whole buttermilk pretty cheap. Here's my go to:
Preheat oven to 450f (you can go higher but I'm paranoid about fumes, long story) if you're using a dutch oven or it in there now.
500g flour (any kind works, bread flour is unsurprisingly the best.)
10 grams salt
9 grams baking soda
About forty grams of sugar (or honey, or brown sugar. I'm sure maple syrup or jaggery would work)
20oz cold buttermilk (I know I'm mixing unit types, but I have a 20oz cup that I use for this and the grams are correct,I just forget what they are(
Mix the dry shit, pour in the wet shit, but save the cup you had the butter milk in.
When there's no more dry powder either spoon it into a well oiled loaf pan, or put it in a disc shape on baking paper.
Now take the buttermilk cup. There should be liquid that was stuck to the sides. Pour that on top and use the back of your mixing spoon to smooth it out. You can score it but you don't need to, this isn't a kneaded dough. If u are using the Dutch oven, use the paper to transfer the disc. Put the loaf pan or dutch oven in.
At 450f this should take a bit over forty minutes, I generally go 42.
I've lately tried adding baking powder to see what happens. I don't really get more rise, but the bread is a bit softer, but it's fine without it.
Let any bread cool completely before slicing.
Other than preheat and bake time, this only takes me a maybe three minutes.
If I have more time I'll make a kneaded or folded yeast bread.

I've looked at how these machines work, and one of the downsides I see is that it could be tripped up by changes in conditions.
If there's variations in flour or humidity it would be unable to detect or compensate.
I can see that if you just want a regular sandwich loaf and you don't want to bother too much it could be a time saver, but similar to a 3d printer, you got to learn it's quirks and dial it in. Also, it doesn't require it occupy the oven.
I would be too bored by the limitations of the platform, but if I didn't have an oven I would prefer it over store bread for sure.
I am curious how reliable these machines are. I imagine that is very model and operator dependant.

posts.com:
I made home-made filet-o-fish a couple of weeks ago.

Ingredients

-wonderbread hamburger bun (contains a lot of datem like a mcdonalds bun)
-van de kamp's frozen minced fish patties of wild caught pollock (same fish as mcdonald's)
-kraft tarter sauce
-field american cheese slice

Steamed the buns in a collander for 2 minutes.
Cheese is set out to get up to room temp and then goes straight on the bun out of the steamer, one half slice per sandwich
Pattie goes on the bun right after taking out of the oven.
Tartar sauce squeezed in a cup to get up to room temp before putting the fish in the oven, now slathered generously on the top bun.

The result was WAY BETTER than any of the real filet-o-fish sandwiches I've had. The cheese was the game changer. Much better than what mcdonalds uses.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18916001
You don't have to prep this. It's just grocery shopping. That's why you use frozen patties instead fresh beef, or making out your own patties.
Even by spending more on the frozen patties compared to a roll of beef you're still going to come out ahead compared to McDonalds or any other fast food place.
Also since it is a frozen patty you aren't going to get your hands dirty making them out. Just throw them straight into the skillet. Use a paper plate to make less mess. You should be able to get by with one skillet and one tray to clean when you're done. You could even use some aluminum foil to not have to clean up the tater tot tray. Just place a sheet under the tots.

I'm not into any of this because of health reasons. I'm just a cheap ass who likes fast food but doesn't want to spend $6-12 on it when I can get the same thing either slightly better, the same, or slightly worse at home for $1-3.

A filet-o-fish is almost five fuckin' dollars bro.
My filet-o-fish at home was probably not even $2 and it was superior in every way.

Hey /ck/, novice cook here. Been cooking for a while, but only at a home level and only from personal experience. I'm looking at improving my technique and depth of understanding further, and so have taken to developing and testing recipes by studying various recipes with noteworthy variations between them. For instance, I had sweetened condensed milk, no eggs, but plenty of yolks, and I wanted cookies. So i found standard recipes and adjusted some factors between them to account for the differences. It worked with the measurements I took and wrote down, though I must have missed something, because replicating it created madelines rather than cookies on new go-arounds.

In any case, I'm thinking of collecting and comparing recipes, and developing some more to try. Feel free to post some yourself, and I'll see what I can give in return. I generally use metric mass measures, though I can work volumetrically.

The sign is a subtle joke. The shop is called "Sneed's Feed & Seed", where feed and seed both end in the sound "-eed", thus rhyming with the name of the owner, Sneed. The sign says that the shop was "Formerly Chuck's", implying that the two words beginning with "F" and "S" would have ended with "-uck", rhyming with "Chuck". So, when Chuck owned the shop, it would have been called "Chuck's Fuck and Suck".

There are four things you need for a good burger:

1. Decent beef. This should be self explanatory but the number of dumbfucks who buy cheap ground beef is amazing.
2. Fat. Do not use lean beef. You want *at least* an 80/20 ratio. Add fat, if you must.
3. A good sear. Doubly true if you're doing a smash burger, obviously.
4. Season the outside of the patty when it it is in the pan: salt & black pepper. Ignore all the retards ITT telling you to add onion powder or Worcestershire or whatever. You're making a burger, not meatloaf. Oh and DEFINITELY no egg or breadcrumbs in a beef patty.

>>18913140
Yes, here you go. I gotta sleep now. Later.

How to make rice:
1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.

>>18912771
I've got a Zojirushi rice cooker, and the rice always comes out perfectly.

What I like to do with it is I'll make the maximum amount of rice it will cook at once while I prepare some stir fry veggies/meat. Eat the stir fry over some rice, and throw the rest in the refrigerator for 3+ days.

See the key to making good fried rice, that every Asian mom/granny knows, is your cooked rice needs to sit in the fridge for a few days. Changes the consistency.

Then later on in the week I can take a cheap ass bag or two of frozen veggies, the kind of stuff they sell for $1-2 at the grocery store, eggs, and some chicken or pork (even leftovers work), and cook up some amazing fried rice.

For seasoning you can use the cheap fried rice seasoning packs, or you can just make your own mix of a bunch of different spices that sound good.

The truth is we don't know. Anyone claiming to know anything about red meat is retarded. More people should be honest with the amount of doubt we have when it comes to dietary sciences. The field is a total mess because of it. We have a very limited understanding of what is good/bad and more importantly, WHY IS IT GOOD/BAD.

Eat what you want in moderation. Eat a variety of foods. Exercise. Most evidence suggests diets high in processed foods and preservatives are bad so if I were you, I'd stay away from that but even then, eating it once every couple of weeks isn't a big deal. If you are truly concerned with your health, 1) be born with good genetics, 2) exercise. Diet is inferior in importance to the above two.

Here’s my favorite liver pate recipe
>1lb chicken liver soaked in milk overnight, rinsed THOROUGHLY
>1lb butter melted on stove on low, couple sprigs of thyme (let it chill on low while you do everything else
>1 pint sliced shallot (sweat, set aside)
>1c sliced garlic (sweat, set aside)
>salt livers liberally and sear RARE on high heat
>deglaze with brandy, cook out alcohol, set aside
>blend livers, shallot/garlic and brandy
>emulsify butter slowly
>add 1/4c cream cheese (trust me on this)
>sherry vinegar and salt to taste
>maple syrup to taste if you’d like
>let set overnight

It’s super easy to quenelle even without tempering, the texture is perfect

McD Filet-O-Fish

Learn to can. Canning provides the benefit of giving you nutrient dense water. Water is something you'll be short on almost no matter what. Best thing you can do is get a pressure cooker and learn to can all sorts of shit. Once you're set up it'll cut down food costs. Just by fresh in bulk and get it persevered. Rotate it out to keep everything at peak freshness and continuously improve your skill.
Learn what wild edibles grow in your area, pretty much everywhere has one or two plants that can become staple crops.
Guns are a suckers game. Keep one for self defense and know how to use and clean it. Preferably a shotgun, even if your aim is shit it gets the point across and can be used for small game. Also a lot easier to learn to reload shells.
Stay away from large game, it's worthless since CWD has become so commonplace, not to mention other disease and pollutants. Meat will become a supplement rather than a main, you'll be fine. We lived that way for about 180,000 years

linseed oil is (very) poisonous, making that knife no longer food-safe... You're supposed to treat it the same way you would with the other piece of wood in your kitchen, your cutting board. >>18915272
Make your own hot sauce (salsa) and bring a shit load of chips. It's cheap to make, easy to make, plus you can make it days before. Because it's your recipe, everyone will want to know how to make it.

Throw in a blender:
> Can of whole tomatoes
> Jalepenos (adjust depending on spice level)
> 1/2-1 white (or purple) onion
> 3-6 pieces of garlic (garlic powder will work)
> a handful of cilantro
> salt
> pepper
> cumin
> lime juice

blend it up, taste and adjust until you are good with it.

Ugh. This morning I had 65g left of one coffee. Normally I use 50g per cup. My hand grinder fits 45g in the hopper and 50g in the catch cup. No problem, I can dump halfway. Well, I waited too long to dump the catch cup. The force of the grounds pushed the magnetic catch cup off the grinder and spilled the coffee to the floor.

Fuck it, right? It's my house. I swept up the grounds onto a piece of paper with a paintbrush. Not using the broom–I know what the broom's been in. I recovered 60g. Yes, there was hair in there. Scenario 1: my floor dirt is fucking delicious.
Scenario 2: increased coffee to water ratio is better (this is not ideal because it means more money)
Scenario 3: The floor has sieved the finer fines out of my grounds giving me a cleaner cup (also not ideal because I'll be tempted to waste coffee)

>>18913183
Anon, as a followup since you may not see this until later: excessively bitter flavors frequently come from overextraction which means you might be brewing your coffee too long. You should consider grinding coarser without changing any other variables and see if that makes a difference. If using espresso, consider pulling a shorter shot without changing grind size or grind coarser to get a faster shot. Either way, the extraction of the beans will be less. Another possibility is that the water temperature may be too high which causes more efficient extraction of bitter compounds in coffee. If varying grind size doesn't solve your issue, consider lowering the water temperature 3-5 degrees or so to see if you move in a good direction and continue until you reach where you want to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18913337
No guarantees this will solve your issue but a broad rule of thumb is that harsh bitter flavors are from overextraction and harsh acidity is from underextraction. If acidity and bitterness are both balanced and there's a pleasant almost sweet taste from the espresso then you're right where you want to be. A general rule of thumb is to get your desired amount of coffee out in approximately 30s, which is a surprisingly long time if you're not used to it. If you want 2:1 (30g espresso out for 15g of coffee in) you may need to grind quite fine. If you find your shots are running quick, then you may need to settle for luongo shots at a 3 or 4:1 ratio until you can dial in your grind for more conventional 1.5-2.5 espresso ratios.

Temperature defects are tough to deal with because typically only really high-end machines will have custom temperature settings. Hoffman says that temp defects are typically not that severe compared to extraction defects so grind size and its effect on shot timing are more important.

Another factor a lot of lower-end machines run into is channeling because the pumps run at too high of pressure. You end up with underextracted and overextracted areas which creates the worst of both worlds. Adding a puck screen in forces even flow over the puck and if your machine is modifiable with an lower-pressure OPV spring (9 bar is considered standard) then I would recommend making that modification because it's easy and cheap to do. My Gaggia runs at 15 bar stock which is way too high, the 9 bar spring will set that as the new upper limit.

Yeah, it just sounds like you want stronger coffee. Simple answer is to use more coffee. If 50g to 500ml is too strong, back it down to 40g/500ml. I do single cup pourovers at 50g/500ml. Thing about these internet guys who do "recipes" is that there's no accounting for taste. Most people prefer a weaker brewed coffee. The important thing to understand is how to change the cup to suit your tastes. Going finer and finer with the grind will eventually give you a more bitter, overextracted cup, yet still be watery. So, go a bit coarser to eliminate fines, steep a bit longer to account for the lessened surface area, use more coffee.

Most important thing with fried rice is you wanna have all your ingredients ready to go, everything chopped and prepped ahead of time cuz the best fried rice is cooked fast. This includes the protein. I usually cook the egg and meat right before but Ieftover stuff is fine too.

I use a wok on a shitty electric coil stove on high heat, season with peanut oil, start with shallot or onion, carrot, garlic (sometimes ginger) until the carrots are tender. I add in the meat component at this point to warm it up (spam most often, but I've also done rotisserie chicken or strips of beef) then the rice goes in. I try and spread the rice around with as much direct contact with the wok as possible, leave it for a min or so to get crispy, then start tossing the rice on very high heat. After a few minutes of tossing, I make a well and add sambal chili sauce and fry it a bit. Add scallion whites and toss. At this point I taste it, add MSG, salt, pepper, soy sauce, oyster sauce, sesame oil and toss. Taste again and adjust seasoning, toss, serve with chopped green onion and sesame seeds.

>>18908544
Put your empty pan on high heat and let it get hot. Add in some canola/vegetable/peanut oil, anything with a high smoke point and let it coat the entire surface of the pan. Bring up the temp and when the oil starts to smoke, remove than pan from the heat and let it cool down a bit. Use a paper towel to remove any excess oil and you're ready to go. You just got a thin layer of oil to polymerize itself onto the steel and it will now act as a non stick barrier. If you did it right you will be able to crack an egg into your stainless pan with no additional oil and it will slide around on the cooking surface with no effort.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think the big thing is cooking in batches with each type of ingredient done individually. Do your aromatics if you want em, meat, etc. then rice. I typically add egg while doing rice with half the pan separated. I usually prefer a smaller curd, like near risotto style created by stirring it into the rice while still raw.
For the rice, use a decent amount of oil, let that get hot and dump rice in. I use day old rice because in my experience it is much easier to deal with and gives you a better texture. Its not 100% necessary but it should be.
Let it sit for like 1-2 minutes then start stirring it up. Add butter and your dry shit like Salt, Onion Powder (if you don't use onions, its a requirement imo) Pepper, MSG, and Sugar (all to taste. Stir that up until rice is done heating up. Add your other shit to it and let the flavors get to know each other for a minute or two, then ring around the pan with soy sauce and mix it in. Not too much, many people overdue it with the soy sauce and it turns your rice mushy. Finish with the tiniest drizzle of sesame oil and its basically on par with hibachi.
I got my method from watching like hundreds of hibachi videos on youtube and asking some myself for their recipes they use. Its obviously different at home since you cant get that amount of heat

>>18914951
are you just starting? getting good at anything takes practice and time. make the foods you like, start planning your shopping around them. you start realizing patterns in flavor/ingredient combinations. you expand your repertoire by trying new kinds of food, and trying to replicate. i had a few food obsessions after trips to bigger cities, that helped expand my horizons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You have to make a wide variety of recipes, and achieve a certain level of mastery over one or two broad types like understanding what makes a certain category of pasta dish work, how to make a good burger or melt, whatever it might be that you eat often and cook a lot. Once you've gotten a handle on how flavors combine and things cook together and why some things work and other things won't you'll understand how to assemble random shit in a way that makes the best of what you have.

This makes it sound more complicated and intimidating than it is which isn't my intention, it's just a sense you develop when you cook often, like being able to judge how much fat or oil to use for something, how far too cook vegetables to make the texture match, details like that that are usually written for you when you follow a set recipe but require a little expertise when you're winging it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18914951
Learn a a handful of different recipes. Lock them down by heart and understand "why" parts of the process are important and what they're doing.

You can develop your palate and experiment. But you must be willing to make mistakes here.

Here are some examples:
-how to get a Maillard reaction on a protein but not cook it tough
-how to slow cook a tough cut
-how to make a roux
-how to prepare different mother sauces
-how to make your own soup
-baking bread basics or pastries
-how different cultures prepare signature dishes
-what to do with a trinity
-how to season, how much spices to use
-improve your knife skills
-understand heat on a stove top and in an oven

The sky is really the limit. You should just go in with some passion and willingness to learn, fail, and succeed.

heres some practical shit ive been doing lately: if youre cooking a new dish, get enough to make it twice.
cook it once, revise, cook it a second time now improved.

to become a good cook, it comes mostly from experience with ingredients and techniques to achieve what you want out of a dish. that way you can survey the ingredients available and the flavors you can derive from them to find a harmony between everything to form a dish worth eating.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18916961
to give more practical advice: start simple. practice fundamentals at the ingredient level, not the dish level. learn about how to cook specific things well, then worry about finding complimentary flavors to add to that foundation.

for instance, make a perfect bowl of rice. make a perfect scrambled egg, sear a perfect chicken breast. build from there

>>18877773
I came up with the idea for Peat Monster, nice to see it mentioned here. The first batch was a 50/50 blend of Caol Ila and Clynelish (or maybe Ardmore, it was a long time ago lol), both about 10 or 15 years old, aged in ex-bourbon, and bottled at cask strength. It was just called Monster. John Glaser, the founder, didn’t want to make it at first because he didn’t personally enjoy peaty whisky. It turned out to be the blend that put him on the map, so he decided to make it regular production item as Peat Monster, with some water added to lower the proof.

>>18899502
you've gone about it wrong from the start if you thought cheap flavored whiskey would be easier to drink or be free of the quality's of ethanol and how it affects your body.

first learn how to drink(approach it like a hot beverage or soup, less is more, savor it for as long as you can muster and do not do shots). then find what you like to drink(better to have 2 or more bottles poured at once to compare and find your sweetspot). then you combine those aspects and become all that is man(who can appreciate the glass in his hand as well as the drink within).

if you're only looking for inebriation then go down the buttchug path.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18905344
something from Caol Ila, but not bottled by Diageo. so basically any Islay single malt that is branded but never names the distillery is 9/10 times Caol Ila and usually about 1/2 the price of the officially bottled 12 and with better representation of the malt.

in terms of overall taste, Kilchoman Machir Bay is very similar to Ardbeg 10 in my experience, but I enjoy Kilchoman more. it sounds cheesey but you can taste the integrity of the farm-to-bottle aspect in Kilchoman. richer and oilier than Ardbeg without the industrial edge. Machir Bay is usually 5-7 years old with a small amount of sherry maturation, but it tastes like 10 year old whisky where as Ardbeg 10 tastes like younger whisky from less active casks.

If you find a bottle of The 6 Isles, that will be a good adjacent pour. if not that then Ledaig 10. recent batches have been more/less sherried so pay attention to the color if you arent crazy about that combination.
